## 1) `enumerate` — numeruj elementy w pętli

::: {#f36c8d6d .cell execution_count=1}
``` {.python .cell-code}
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for i, f in enumerate(fruits, start=1):
    print(i, f)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
1 apple
2 banana
3 cherry
```
:::
:::


**Dlaczego warto:** zamiast ręcznie liczyć indeksy.

---

## 2) `zip` — paruj listy w locie

::: {#3edf477f .cell execution_count=2}
``` {.python .cell-code}
names = ["Ala", "Bartek", "Cezary"]
scores = [84, 92, 78]
for name, score in zip(names, scores):
    print(f"{name}: {score}")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Ala: 84
Bartek: 92
Cezary: 78
```
:::
:::


**Protip:** `list(zip(names, scores))` da listę krotek.

---

## 3) List Comprehension — szybko twórz listy

::: {#7bd29013 .cell execution_count=3}
``` {.python .cell-code}
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
squares_even = [x*x for x in nums if x % 2 == 0]
squares_even
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11}
```
[4, 16]
```
:::
:::
